Experiment tracking

Lots of moving parts â€¦

Deep learning experiments come with a lot of components:

  • Datasets
  • Model architectures
  • Hyperparameters

While developing an efficient model, various datasets will be trained on various architectures tuned with various hyperparameters

â€¦ making for challenging tracking

*hp = hyperparameter

How did we get performance19 again? ðŸ¤¯

Experiment tracking tools

The solution to this complexity is to use an experiment tracking tool such as MLflow and, optionally, a data versioning tool such as DVC

See our webinar on DVC

MLflow

Platform for AI life cycle

FOSS & compatible

  • Open-source
  • Works with any ML or DL framework
  • Vendor-neutral if you run a server on a commercial platform
  • Can be combined with dvc for dataset versioning
  • Works with any hyperparameter tuning framework  âž”  e.g. integration with Optuna
     â€‚â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚ integration with Ray Tune
     â€‚â€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€ƒâ€‚ integration with hyperopt

Used by many proprietary tools

The foundation of many proprietary no-code/low-code tuning platforms that just add a layer on top to interface with the user with text rather than code

e.g. Microsoft Fabric, FLAML

Limitations

MLflow projects do not (yet) support uv

Some functionality missing for deployment and production for large companies (but irrelevant for research and no FOSS option exists)

Installing MLflow

With uv

Create a uv project:

uv init --bare

Install MLflow:

uv add mlflow

Tracking models

Overview

Track models at checkpoints

Compare with different datasets

Visualize with tracking UI

Definitions

Run:
Single execution of a model training event

Model signature:
Description of a modelâ€™s input and output data structure, data types, and features names

MLflow tracking setups

MLflow tracking setups

Local

import mlflow

mlflow.set_experiment("<experiment-name>")

Logs get stored in an mlruns directory

This method will be deprecated, so prefer the use of a database

MLflow tracking setups

Local with database

import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("sqlite:///mlflow.db")
mlflow.set_experiment("<experiment-name>")

Here we use SQLite which works well for a local database

Logs get stored in an mlflow.db file

MLflow tracking setups

Remote tracking server

For team development

import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://<host>:<port>")
mlflow.set_experiment("<experiment-name>")

MLflow user interface

MLflow UI

Local

mlflow server

The server listens on http://localhost:5000 by default, but you can choose any unused port:

mlflow server --port 8080

MLflow UI

Local with database

mlflow server \
       --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db

(Default port is 5000)

With another port:

mlflow server \
       --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db \
       --port 8080

MLflow UI

Remote tracking server

mlflow server \
       --host <host> \
       --backend-store-uri postgresql+psycopg2://<username>:<password>@<host>:<port>/mlflowdb \
       --port <port>

Here we use PostgreSQL which works well to manage a database in a collaborative remote client-server system

(Requires installing the psycopg2 package)

Access the UI

Open http://<host>:<port> in your browser

Example:

For a local server on port 5000 (the default), open http://localhost:5000/

Log tracking data

The workflow looks like this:

import mlflow

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.log_param("lr", 0.001)
    # Your ml code
    ...
    mlflow.log_metric("val_loss", val_loss)

Organize runs

experiments child runs tags

Tracking datasets

Hyperparameter tuning

Goal of tuning

Find the optimal set of hyperparameters that maximize a modelâ€™s predictive accuracy and performance

âž” Find the right balance between high bias (underfitting) and high variance (overfitting) to improve the modelâ€™s ability to generalize and perform well on new, unseen data

Tuning frameworks

Hyperparameters optimization used to be done manually following a systematic grid pattern. This was extremely inefficient

Nowadays, there are many frameworks that do it automatically, faster, and better

Example:

  • Optuna
  • Hyperopt
  • Ray Tune

Workflow

  • Define an objective function
  • Define a search space
  • Minimize the objective over the space
